titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Kango Takamura Paintings LSC.0433
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Laura Ward, October 2003, revised by Octavio Olvera, 2016; machine-readable finding aid created by Caroline Cubé.

p.date: Online finding aid last updated 2019 April 16.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-08-24 13:22:46 -0700.

did.abstract: Kango Takamura (1895-1990) was an photo retoucher for RKO Studios in Los Angeles when Pearl Harbor was attacked by the Japanese Imperial Navy. He was detained by the FBI in 1942 after offering to sell a motion-picture camera to a visiting Japanese general. He was interned at Santa Fe, New Mexico for several months and then moved to a camp at Manzanar, California, where he joined his wife, daughter, son-in-law and granddaughter. He remained at Manzanar with his family until 1945. While at Manzanar, Takamura depicted his surroundings in drawings and watercolors. He also worked as a camp sign-maker at Santa Fe and as curator for a small museum at Manzanar. After the war, he returned to Hollywood and worked at RKO Studios for another twenty-five years before retiring. The collection consists of 77 watercolor paintings produced during World War II while Kango Takamura was detained at the Santa Fe Internment Camp, New Mexico, and the Manzanar Internment Camp, California. Also included are paper mounts and one photographic reproduction of a painting.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Reproduction and Use
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Kango Takamura paintings (Collection 433). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.
Processed by Laura Ward, October 2003, revised by Octavio Olvera, 2016.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Kango Takamura was an Issei artist born in Kumamoto-ken, Japan in January of 1895. He immigrated to the United States when he was seventeen years old. Takamura spent ten years in Hawaii and then went to New York after becoming interested in the motion picture industry. After a short stay at the Paramount Studios offices in Long Island he moved to Hollywood. He was working as a photo retoucher for RKO Studios in Los Angeles when Pearl Harbor was attacked by the Japanese Imperial Navy. Takamura was detained by the FBI in 1942 after offering to sell a motion-picture camera to a visiting Japanese general. He was interned at Santa Fe, New Mexico for several months and then moved to a camp at Manzanar, California, where he joined his wife, daughter, son-in-law and granddaughter. He remained at Manzanar with his family until 1945. Takamura was not allowed to take photographs during his stays at Santa Fe and Manzanar but he depicted his surroundings in drawings and watercolors. He also worked as a camp sign-maker at Santa Fe and as curator for a small museum at Manzanar. When Takamura left Manzanar he returned to Hollywood and worked at RKO Studios for another twenty-five years before retiring. Takamura lived in Los Angeles until he passed away in January, 1990 at 94 years old.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of 77 watercolor paintings produced during World War II while Kango Takamura was detained at the Santa Fe Internment Camp, New Mexico, and the Manzanar Internment Camp, California. Also included are paper mounts and one photographic reproduction of a painting.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in the following series:
Santa Fe.
Manzanar.
The series names identify the place where the paintings in each series were produced.

controlaccess.subject: Japanese Americans -- Evacuation and relocation, 1942-1945
controlaccess.corpname: Santa Fe Internment Camp (N.M.) -- Pictorial works
Manzanar War Relocation Center -- Pictorial works

did.physdesc: (21 × 29 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper, matted)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Our pet hawk died on May 22. The following day Mr. Sato of Chula Vista died. But same day over 80 of us internees were released."

did.unittitle: Our guard became a spring baseball fan,
did.physdesc: (21 × 28 cm. Watercolor and pencil on paper, matted)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Our guard in the watch tower became a spring baseball fan at Santa Fe."

did.unittitle: At evening I sketched this unusual cloud formation,
did.physdesc: (25.5 × 37.5 cm. Watercolor on paper, matted)

did.unittitle: Surprised guard on night watch at Santa Fe,
did.physdesc: (27.5 × 42.5 cm. Watercolor and ink on heavy paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "His bald pate shined as bright as a full moon."
[Also], Pencil and ink sketches of women in kimono verso.

did.unittitle: Panorama of Santa Fe internment center and mount,
did.physdesc: (Painting 13 × 25 cm; mount 20 × 28 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper. Mount is card stock and rice paper with ink caption)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Signed with Japanese characters. Caption on mount reads: "Panorama of Santa Fe internment center. Drawn on writing paper - with anxiety - during early days when I was not sure that drawings of any kind were permitted."

did.physdesc: (19.5 × 28 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Mr. Ohkado, Mr. Nozaki R., Mr. Kitagawa M."

did.unittitle: An adobe house inside our Santa Fe camp,
did.physdesc: (17.5 × 29 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "An adobe house inside our Santa Fe Camp."

did.physdesc: (21 × 30.5 cm. Watercolor and pencil on paper)
(20.5 × 29 cm. Watercolor, ink, and pencil on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Mr. Higashikuze. Our umpire Mr. Higashikuze knew the rules but the players dint it. However we all had a good time."

did.unittitle: This was the Santa Fe barrack no.5,
did.physdesc: (21 × 21.5 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "This was the Santa Fe barrack no.5 where I stayed."

did.physdesc: (20.5 × 29.5 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "A butane tank was used to strike the gong that summoned us to mess hall. Santa Fe internment camp."

did.physdesc: (19.5 × 29.5 cm. Watercolor, ink, and pencil on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "June 1942. Ending months of uncertainty, we were released from Santa Fe internment camp to return to our families at relocation centers. Everyone cheered as we left camp. Now there was hope we would return home."

did.physdesc: (36 × 25.5 cm. Watercolor, ink, and pencil on paper)

did.unittitle: We stopped briefly at a small town,
did.physdesc: (20.5 × 28.5 cm. Watercolor, ink, and pencil on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "We stopped briefly at a small town - Needles, they said. To our pleasant surprise, Japanese workers brought us boxes of food."

did.physdesc: (19.5 × 27 cm. Watercolor, ink, and pencil on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Mojave, Calif. We waited for our bus here for seven long hours in a desert windstorm - after we disembarked from the train."

did.physdesc: (Paper)

did.unittitle: Our roommates in barracks no. five,
did.physdesc: (38.9 × 57.5 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper, matted. Source of title noted in pencil verso)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Mr. Okaski, Mr. Sugiyama, Mr. Tsuyuki, Mr. Hagio, Mr. Yamamoto, Mr. Tanaka, Mr. Hatori, Mr. Yamada, Mr. Musashi, Mr. Takamura."

did.physdesc: (21 × 28.5 cm. Watercolor, ink, and pencil on paper, matted)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Making rice cakes (mochi-tsuki). New Year custom. No 2 kitchen."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Mr. Hirozawa. The chemists work incessantly in search of a better method of extracting rubber. Here a chemist is preparing latex from guayule."

did.physdesc: (19.5 × 25 cm. Watercolor [?] and ink on paper, matted)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "The first successful growing of -- guayule rubber plant cuttings."

did.physdesc: (22 × 32 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper and inset black and white photograph, matted)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Progress after one year. The mess hall line."
With inset photo caption: "Wall painting by Takamura."

did.physdesc: (25.5 × 36 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper, matted)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Rooted cuttings are transplanted to milk cartons and then to the field. Transplanting is done carefully and speedily by hand of the experimenters. Mr. Akaboshi."

did.physdesc: (23.5 × 41.5 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Manzanar High School commencement of 1944. Our democratic country has people representing all nation[s] -- Mr. Ralph P. Merritt."

did.physdesc: (24.5 × 39 cm. Watercolor on paper)

did.unittitle: Keeping the camp clean and tidy,
did.physdesc: (37.5 × 51 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)
(37 × 27.5 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "A huge blender speedily stirring gallons of water mixed with chopped guayule, forces rubber out of the wood. This is a mechanical method which has been proved most efficient in extracting rubber from guayule shrubs."

did.physdesc: (26.5 × 36.5 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Mr. Nishimura. Analysis of the plant extracts is one of many research works which are carried out by the chemists. Here a chemist is working with a special apparatus for the determination of nitrogen."

did.physdesc: (36 × 50.5 cm. Watercolor on paper)

did.unittitle: Saturday afternoon looking south from block 8,
did.physdesc: (31.5 × 50.5 cm. Watercolor on paper)
(26.5 × 37 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Propagation of plants by cutting method has been succeeded for the first time. Guayule cuttings are treated with a phytohormone before setting in a flat."

did.physdesc: (21 × 28 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Home sweet home for men coming home to Manzanar from [feet] furlough."

did.physdesc: (21.5 × 29 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)
(21.5 × 29.5 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "I visited Dr. Carter today because school has opened and I am to make drawings of class scenes. It seemed a hundred people were rushing in and out of her office. All over her desk; the telephone rang all the time."

did.physdesc: (22 × 28.5 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "It's nap time, but there's more noise than rest. The youngsters wriggle around, won't lie still. The teachers look exhausted. The scam in the foreground turns around: 'Hiya popa, watcha doin?' Rest time in the nursery class."

did.physdesc: (20 × 29 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)
(22 × 26.5 cm. Watercolor, ink, and pencil on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "'Teacher, I know - ' At the other end of the same barrack. First graders of Miss Joh sit awkwardly about the mess table. A question has just been asked. Little Hiroshi, on the end slowly lifts his hand 'Teacher, I know.'"

did.unittitle: Did you ever see such individual dress attire?,
did.physdesc: (21 cm × 28 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Did you ever see such individual dress attire? This is a high school gym class I ran into on the dusty field next to block 7. Facing each other in a circle, they would clap their hands, say something, laugh. Off in the corner another class came dashing by in a cloud of dust. But school is wonderful."

did.physdesc: (22 × 30 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "A cooking class. What vitamins do potatoes have? Miss Smith teaches her girls in what used to be the kitchen of mess hall 7."

did.physdesc: (22.5 × 29.5 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "'Gee, that angleworm's my name.' said Haruo, slouched over the classroom steps as Mr. Lamphere showed his shorthand pupils how to write their name in the Gregg manner."

did.unittitle: The boys in the woodcarving class,
did.physdesc: (21.5 × 29 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "The boys in the woodcarving class of Mr. Bouche were being praised for their good work that day. The teacher was kept very busy showing his pupils how to hold the chisel."

did.physdesc: (21 × 29 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Manzanar High School. Studies took on great importance in these barrack classrooms. This was a day before the week-end holiday."

did.physdesc: (21.5 × 28 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Roll call is taken. This was first day of school he study hall. Converted from a former mess hall, resounded with laughter as Mr. Vanderjagt aide would call a name and a squeaky soprano would respond 'Here,' only to be followed by an off-pitch bass 'Heah.' Unsigned.

did.physdesc: (20 × 30.5 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Students hurry to the classes as the bell rings on this foggy morning."

did.physdesc: (22 × 30.5 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Approximately 200 students graduated at second Manzanar High School commencement."

(22 × 33 cm. Watercolor on paper)

did.unittitle: The residents transformed dusty semi-arid land,
did.physdesc: (20 × 29 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "The residents transformed dusty semi-arid land into green truck forms, growing vegetable crops of all kinds. I sketched this scene of workers harvesting large, ripe, sweet watermelons."

did.physdesc: (17 × 28.5 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)
(22 × 28.5 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Farm workers harvest a crop of Manzanar grown okra."

did.physdesc: (20 × 25 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Guayule shrub and leaf types. Some of the leaf types can be used to distinguish one strain from another."

did.physdesc: (24 × 35 cm. Watercolor and ink on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "A biologist hybridizes Guayule trying to produce plants superior in quality than those existing now."

did.unittitle: After the rain an abandoned baby cart,
did.physdesc: (22.5 × 35 cm. Watercolor on paper)
(16 × 29.5 cm. Watercolor, ink, and pencil on paper)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "The Manzanar auditorium and community hall nears completion."
